Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Hydrothermal Carbonization of Mixed Feedstocks: Implications for Sustainable Waste Management

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1055327 PI Berge

The PI will explore hydrothermal carbonization (HTC) as a treatment process that sustainably promotes carbon sequestration and value-added product production from waste streams. The specific objectives of this work are to: (1) understand how the interaction between compounds (e.g., cellulose and lignin) and catalyst addition influences the HTC process, (2) elucidate the mechanisms associated with emerging contaminant fate in the HTC processes, and (3) integrate research and education to increase student and practitioner awareness of HTC and the sustainability of waste utilization. A series of laboratory experiments will be conducted to understand how reaction conditions and mixtures of compounds influence HTC processes. HTC reaction rates, activation energies, end-product characteristics, and process energetics (i.e., heat of reaction), as well as the capacity of the process to effectively treat emerging contaminants, are important when considering its use as a waste treatment technique. This research will identify how mixtures of compounds influence HTC reaction characteristics for feedstocks representing common waste streams. Correlations between feedstock, process conditions, carbon sequestration, process water quality, and hydrochar quality will be established. This research is transformative in that it is the first study evaluating HTC (reaction kinetics, process energetic, etc.) of waste materials and will result in an extensive data set for evaluating a technology that has global implications.

Integration of research and education is a critical component of this work. Significant efforts will be made to introduce HTC and waste sustainability issues to students (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate students) and practitioners. Specific activities include: (1) development of an undergraduate level problem-based laboratory course in environmental engineering, (2) development and implementation of a program that can be applied to middle school classrooms to increase student and teacher awareness to environmental engineering issues and careers, (3) conduct workshops to educate practitioners about HTC, and (3) continue mentoring of underrepresented students and involving them in research and educational activities.

In terms of the broader impacts, results from this work will aid in current policy discussions with respect to climate change, clean and renewable energy, and environmental impact of our waste-related processes. The PI will promote teaching, training, and learning while conducting this research, particularly with respect to underrepresented groups. The PI will continue to mentor young students through collaborations with an HBCU college located in Columbia, SC. A large population of potential future engineers and scientists will be reached via the K-12 education/outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall focus of this CAREER grant was to explore the use of hydrothermal carbonization as a waste treatment process to sustainably promote carbon sequestration and value-added product production from wet waste streams. Hydrothermal carbonization is a wet, relatively low temperature thermal conversion process that occurs under autogenous pressures. This process has gained significant attention for its ability to convert wet organic wastes to value-added solid, liquid, and gas products. Prior to the work conducted during this project, few studies were conducted exploring the use of hydrothermal carbonization as a sustainable waste management technique. The specific objectives of this project included: (1) Understanding how the interaction between compounds found in mixed feedstocks and catalyst addition influences the HTC process, (2) Elucidating the mechanisms associated with emerging contaminant fate in the hydrothermal carbonization processes, and (3) Integrating research and education to increase student and practitioner awareness of HTC and waste sustainability.

 

To meet these objectives, a series of laboratory experiments were conducted to understand how reaction conditions (e.g., time, temperature, and initial solids concentrations), different types of wet wastes, and different mixtures of compounds found in wastes influence hydrothermal carbonization processes and generated carbonization product characteristics. Work was also conducted to understand nutrient fate during the hydrothermal carbonization process to ascertain the agricultural value of the generated products. In addition, a database containing all hydrothermal carbonization-related data reported in the literature was compiled and used to develop linear and non-linear models to describe hydrochar characteristics and identify the most influential feedstock properties and/or process conditions. A life cycle assessment was also conducted to understand potential environmental implications from this process.

 

Results from this study indicate that the hydrothermal carbonization of wet wastes is feasible, environmentally advantageous, and results in the generation of value-added solid, liquid, and gas products. The solid product, referred to as hydrochar, is of particular interest because of its high carbon and energy content. Following carbonization, the majority of carbon and energy present in the feedstock remains integrated within the hydrochar, resulting in a material that may be used in a variety of applications (e.g., energy source, soil amendment). Results from this work also indicate that feedstocks with high moisture and carbon content, such as the organic fraction of municipal solid waste, are ideally suited for conversion via hydrothermal carbonization, and that reaction time and temperature have a significant influence on the carbonization process and thus carbonization product characteristics. It was also determined that carbonization process conditions primarily influence solid yields and liquid and gas-phase carbon contents, while feedstock properties were found to be more influential on hydrochar carbon and energy contents and the normalized carbon content of the solid. Results from a life cycle assessment suggest hydrothermal carbonization may be environmentally advantageous, but the type and extent of environmental benefits associated with HTC are dependent on HTC-generated product use. One potential use of the hydrochar is as a fertilizer. Results from nutrient distribution studies associated with the carbonization of food waste suggest that up to 0.96% and 2.30% of nitrogen and phosphorus-based fertilizers, respectively, in the US can be replaced by the nutrients integrated within hydrochar and liquid-phases generated from the carbonization of currently landfilled food wastes.

 

This project has also made a significant impact on the teaching and training of students. Two new undergraduate level courses were developed as a result of this grant, one focusing on the research process and another focusing on life cycle assessment.  In addition, a program to increase student and teacher awareness to environmental engineering issues and careers was implemented in a local middle school. This grant also provided training, mentoring, and professional development for several PhD, undergraduate, and high school students. The results from this grant were widely disseminated through several peer-reviewed articles, conference papers, and conference presentations.
